subject: UpdateService: Support for MultipartHttpPushUri

comments.message:
Patch Set 1: Ok-To-Test+1

User approved, CI ok to start

Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Build Failed 

https://openpower.xyz/job/openbmc-repository-ci/49240/ : FAILURE

Patch Set 2: Ok-To-Test+1

User approved, CI ok to start

Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build Successful 

https://openpower.xyz/job/openbmc-repository-ci/49245/ : SUCCESS

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

How is this multipart ?
HTTP Multipart means: one or more different sets of data are combined in a single body.

The request should have header like {contenttype: multipart/form-data} and the server side we should have handled this header.

Patch Set 2:

Eg of Multipart Data

POST / HTTP/1.1
Host: localhost:8000
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux i686; rv:29.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/29.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Cookie: __atuvc=34%7C7; permanent=0; _gitlab_session=226ad8a0be43681acf38c2fab9497240; __profilin=p%3Dt; request_method=GET
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=---------------------------9051914041544843365972754266
Content-Length: 554

-----------------------------9051914041544843365972754266
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="text"

text default
-----------------------------9051914041544843365972754266
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="file1"; filename="a.txt"
Content-Type: text/plain

Content of a.txt.

-----------------------------9051914041544843365972754266
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="file2"; filename="a.html"
Content-Type: text/html

<!DOCTYPE html><title>Content of a.html.</title>

-----------------------------9051914041544843365972754266--

Patch Set 27:

(34 comments)

Despite the number of comments, this is looking much....much.....much better than the last version.  I'll bet it's also much smaller code-wise as well.  There is still a bunch of error handling that is neglected, and some of the code organization needs to change to handle those properly, but this is so much closer to something mergable.

Good job!

Patch Set 29:

For what it's worth, I dug up my last attempt for what I was thinking (about adding it to http request instead putting it in each handler)

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/34974

It covers most of James suggestions, merges the reader and parser classes into 1, handles errors (I missed 1, but it's commented as a todo) and adds MIME as a first class type in bmcweb.  Feel free to use it as an example, in whole, part, or not at all.

Patch Set 35:

(5 comments)

As a general rule, we should avoid reimplementing things that beast already includes.

Please look at boost/beast/http/rfc7230.hpp, instead of implementing argument parsing yourself, it is more likely to be correct.

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/44395/ : SUCCESS
why are we removing support for this?

Do we need to support MultipartHttpPushUri and HttpPushUri at the same time?
I think so and fixed it.

missing reference for all of these

https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/reference#Lvalue_references
please check coding standard about variable naming
Don't we need to handle Targets and Oem of UpdateParameters?

For now, should only parse the applyTime property and update d-bus.
right?
have you tested the update with the uploaded image? Does the image binary received as same or any headers were added to it by multi-part?

>have you tested the update with the uploaded image? 
yes, upload and update image success.

>by multi-part?
sorry, according to the redfish spec, we need to use the octet-stream type to receive the image binary instead of multi-part.
http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.8.0.html#multipart-http-push-updates-a-id-http-push-update-a-

I don't see the implementation is correct, as per the redfish spec, the request should have been like this.

MultiPart request should have the boundary tag, You ccan see the implementation in following commit.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/31030


POST /redfish/v1/UpdateService/upload HTTP/1.1
Host: <host-path>
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=---------------------------d74496d66958873e
Content-Length: <computed-length>
Connection: keep-alive
X-Auth-Token: <session-auth-token>

-----------------------------d74496d66958873e
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="UpdateParameters"
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "Targets": [
        "/redfish/v1/Managers/1"
    ],
    "@Redfish.OperationApplyTime": "OnReset",
    "Oem": {}
}

-----------------------------d74496d66958873e
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="UpdateFile"; filename="flash.bin"
Content-Type: application/octet-stream

<software image binary>

I just used this patch and tried update using postman tool, the image file has got appended with 2 bytes at the end of the file. Can you also test with postman and check? I used postman as below.


POST https://10.190.164.182/redfish/v1/UpdateService/upload
KEY
UpdateParameters
VALUE 
{"Targets":"/redfish/v1/Managers/1"],"@Redfish.OperationApplyTime":"Immediate","Oem":{}}
CONTENT TYPE
application/json

KEY
UpdateFile
VALUE
bmc_signed_cap-20200515120637.bin
CONTENT TYPE
application/octet-stream

@Vikram B
>bmc_signed_cap-20200515120637.bin
It should be *.tar, please see my commit message, thanks :)

@Rata
>I don't see the implementation is correct
could you point out where is not correct? thanks.
issues about this commit: https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/dev/issues/1372.

>MultiPart request should have the boundary tag
right.
I printed the following message from this commit.

POST /redfish/v1/UpdateService/upload HTTP/1.1
Host: <host-path>
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=---------------------------91b83fcd225fffac
Content-Length: <computed-length>
Connection: keep-alive
X-Auth-Token: <session-auth-token>

-----------------------------91b83fcd225fffac
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="UpdateParameters"
Content-Type: application/json

{
    "Targets": [
        "/redfish/v1/Managers/1"
    ],
    "@Redfish.OperationApplyTime": "Immediate",
    "Oem": {}
}

-----------------------------91b83fcd225fffac
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="UpdateFile"; filename="obmc-phosphor-image-fp5280g2.static.mtd.tar"
Content-Type: application/octet-stream

<software image binary>

@Liu, With HttpPushUri we could earlier use both .bin and .tar files on the binary POST body. This changing prompting for changes in the back end (i.e. phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt) where uploaded image is need to be parsed. We need to know why binary image upload is not working with form-data.

@george : This is what I got from the commit message 


curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $token" -H "Content-Type:
multipart/form-data" -F
"UpdateParameters={\"Targets\":[\"/redfish/v1/Managers/1\"],\"@Redfish.OperationApplyTime\":\"Immediate\",\"Oem\":{}};type=appalication/json"
-F
"UpdateFile=@obmc-phosphor-image.static.mtd.tar;type=application/octet-stream"
https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/UpdateService/upload
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/0",
  "@odata.type": "#Task.v1_4_3.Task",
  "Id": "0",
  "TaskState": "Running",
  "TaskStatus": "OK"
} 


As per the redfish spec(http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.8.0.html#multipart-http-push-updates-a-id-http-push-update-a-) the request should have been like this.

POST /redfish/v1/UpdateService/upload HTTP/1.1
Host: <host-path>
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=---------------------------d74496d66958873e
Content-Length: <computed-length>
Connection: keep-alive
X-Auth-Token: <session-auth-token>

-----------------------------d74496d66958873e
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="UpdateParameters"

https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/UpdateService_v1.xml is only allowed at /redfish/v1/UpdateService and  "MultipartHttpPushUri" is a URI in UpdateService_v1 that allows a POST. 



                "MultipartHttpPushUri": {
                    "description": "The URI used to perform a Redfish Specification-defined Multipart HTTP or HTTPS push update to the Update Service.",
                    "format": "uri-reference",
                    "longDescription": "This property shall contain a URI used to perform a Redfish Specification-defined Multipart HTTP or HTTPS POST of a software image for the purpose of installing software contained within the image.",
                    "readonly": true,
                    "type": "string",
                    "versionAdded": "v1_6_0"
                },

Please document how much this adds to the binary size of the openbmc image.

Hi Ed,

There was a difference of 71.68 KB in the openbmc flash size.

This was mailed to the community before this library was pulled in openbmc.
I must've missed that.  Apologies.  Have you tried to reduce the size at all?  For simply parsing MIME types, 71kB is a lot of code.

So, for example, this parser: https://github.com/FooBarWidget/multipart-parser

Is a single header that we could just include here.  When compiled with the same flags that bmcweb uses, and gzip compressed, it compresses down to 8.3kB, which is much closer to what I would expect for a simple parser like this, and nearly 10X smaller.  By any chance, did you take a look at that parser before you included this one?  Looking at the API, it's also a parser style, which means that we can directly link it to the request body type in beast, and reduce our memory footprint for large files even more.


compile flags:
g++ --std=c++17 -Os -flto -fno-rtti -fvisibility=hidden -fvisibility-inlines-hidden -Wl,--exclude-libs,ALL multipart.cpp
gzip a.out
ls -alh a.out.gz
➜  multipart-parser git:(master) ✗ ls -alh a.out.gz
-rwxrwxr-x 1 ed ed 8.3K Jul 13 14:34 a.out.gz


Digging more into mimetic it's very clear why it's large: it implements a number of library features for internal data structures (presumably for speed).  The one i linked relies on std library implementations, which the bmc already has, so it requires nothing to add.

It should be noted, in the case where I pointed out that mimetic can't tell the difference between a parse error and a missing key, this one has a feed() call, that returns the characters parsed, and can be compared directly.

Overall, on first glance, I suspect it's a much better fit for the project.

sure.
but can we customize resolution without relying on any library?
like this:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/32174/6/redfish-core/lib/update_service.hpp#658

If you want to write a compliant single-pass parser that doesn't hardcode the paths you need, then sure, that's fine, but the one you linked is definitely not compliant.  If you want to write your own parser, I'd start with something like the MultiPartParser object from the library I linked, then adapt it to your needs in a generic way that can be used by others.

Hi Ed,

The parser that you have pointed to, I see that the single header can be included in order to use it, but seems it has not been updated for 4 years.
Mimetic lib is being updated, at least when compared to the parser, and seems to be used in distros.

Speaking of the errors, I think we have internal methods to build/parse the mimetic header and body, with which we can handle the errors.

Any thoughts, Ed?

It should be noted, the MIME multipart spec hasn't changed in a long long time.  It's unlikely that such a small library with so few features (but importantly, the features we need) would need significant updating.  With that said, that was only an example.  See my commit where I move it to bmcweb styling, and remove the parts we don't need to turn it into a 490 line diff.  This is less code than a lot of our route handlers.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/34974

As far as disk usage, 77KB of disk usage for mimentic, versus 1448 bytes for the parser in my commit.  This order of magnitude difference need to be reconciled before I'd ever consider mimentic.  That's not to say it's not good or high quality, but someone needs to spend the time to optimize, and compartmentalize the build to remove the things we don't need..... Or, we can just test and use an in-bmcweb parser that very little code.  For my effort, the later is easier.

When you say "internal methods" what do you mean?  Methods we'd have to patch from private to public to use?

I meant there are methods (public), that we could use while parsing to determine the presence of each element, for error-handling.

> As far as disk usage, 77KB of disk usage for mimentic, versus 1448 bytes for the parser in my commit.  This order of magnitude difference need to be reconciled before I'd ever consider mimentic.  That's not to say it's not good or high quality, but someone needs to spend the time to optimize, and compartmentalize the build to remove the things we don't need.....
